elements.content: Energetic metal–organic frameworks (EMOFs) with a high oxygen content are currently a hot spot in the field of energetic materials research. In this article, two series of EMOFs with different ligands were obtained by reacting 1-(trinitromethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic acid (tntrza) with metal iodide and metal nitrate, respectively. Furthermore, their structure, thermal stability, thermal decomposition kinetics, and energy performance are fully characterized. The research results revealed that the synthesized EMOFs possess a wide range of density (ρ = 1.88∼2.595 g cm–3), oxygen balance (OB­(CO2) = −21.1∼ −4.3%), and acceptable energy performance (D = 7.73∼8.74 km s–1 and P = 28.1∼41.1 GPa). The difference in OB­(CO2) caused by the ligand structure and metal properties has a great impact on the distribution of gas-phase products after the decomposition of these EMOFs. Noteworthy, [Ag­(tntrza)] n is particularly prominent among these EMOFs, not only because of its excellent detonation performance (D = 8.74 km s–1 and P = 41.1 GPa) endowed by its extremely high density (ρ = 2.595 g cm–3) and oxygen balance (OB­(CO2) = −4.3%) but also because of its effective catalytic effect on the decomposition of ammonium perchlorate (AP). This article broadens the horizon for the study of oxygen-enriched EMOFs with catalytic effects and helps understand the mechanism of thermal decomposition of EMOFs with nitroform and dinitro groups.

elements.content: Energetic materials, including explosives, propellants, and explosives, are widely used in military and civilian areas because of their characteristic of rapid chemical energy release during the self-redox reaction. In the past few decades, driven by the huge demand for new energetic materials in national defense and aerospace, high-energy-dense materials (HEDMs) with advanced properties have ushered in unprecedented development, and some of them play an indispensable role in the abovementioned special areas. Even so, there are still huge barriers (such as a density higher than 2.2 g cm–3) to the development of traditional organic energetic compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Energetic materials, including explosives, propellants, and explosives, are widely used in military and civilian areas because of their characteristic of rapid chemical energy release during the self-redox reaction. In the past few decades, driven by the huge demand for new energetic materials in national defense and aerospace, high-energy-dense materials (HEDMs) with advanced properties have ushered in unprecedented development, and some of them play an indispensable role in the abovementioned special areas. Even so, there are still huge barriers (such as a density higher than 2.2 g cm-3) to the development of traditional organic energetic compounds.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks based on energetic materials (EMOFs) have received continuous attention since they were reported. Compared with traditional organic energetic compounds, EMOFs have promising controllability in terms of loading density, energy performance, and stability, and it is these advanced characteristics that make EMOFs widely used in detonating devices, pyrotechnic, heat-resistant explosives, and catalysts in propellants. The use of nitrogen-rich materials as building blocks to construct EMOFs has aroused great interest because of the existence of extensive C–N, CN, N–N, NN, and N–O energy bonds as well as environmental-friendly features. However, MOFs prepared with nitrogen heterocycles without other oxygen-containing functional groups as ligands tend to reduce the overall oxygen content of the charge because most metals themselves also need to consume oxygen during the combustion or explosion of EMOFs. In order to improve these disadvantages, nitrogen heterocycles with oxygen-containing functional groups (such as nitro, carboxyl, carbonyl, and hydroxyl) are widely used to prepare EMOFs with enhanced oxygen content (). Among these oxygen-containing groups, nitro, dinitro, and nitroform structures are very effective oxidizing components, especially nitroform, which is usually used to prepare organic oxidants with high energy density characteristics. It is worth noting that the increase in the number of nitro groups on the structure of energetic materials (or the introduction of the nitroform structure) is usually accompanied by a decrease in thermal stability. Therefore, how to achieve a good balance of thermal stability and high oxygen content is an obstacle in the study of EMOFs.

elements.content: Based on the above description, we designed and successfully prepared a new energetic ligand 1-(trinitromethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic acid (tntrza) with a high oxygen content (C). Also, by reacting tntrza with metal iodide and metal nitrate, EMOFs ([K­(dntrza)] n , [Rb­(dntrza)] n , and [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ) based on 1-(dinitromethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic acid (dntrza), as well as EMOFs ([K­(tntrza)] n and [Ag­(tntrza)] n ) based on tntrza were prepared, respectively (). Furthermore, through X-ray single crystal diffraction, differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), BAM friction sensitivity tester and fall hammer impact sensitivity tester, and Kamlet-Jacobs equations, their crystal structure, thermal stability, mechanical sensitivity, and detonation performance were investigated. In addition, the catalytic effect of [Ag­(tntrza)] n on ammonium perchlorate (AP) was also explored.

elements.content: The preparation process of EMOFs based on dntrza and tntrza is shown in . The synthesis process of the new energetic ligand and the MOF derived therefrom is given in detail in the Supporting Information. Originally, the purpose of the reaction between tntrza and metal iodide (KI, RbI, and CsI) in methanol was to prepare a MOF based on tntrza. However, a MOF with dinitro groups ([K­(dntrza)] n , [Rb­(dntrza)] n , and [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ) was unexpectedly obtained. The results of this reaction are consistent with those previously reported by Kofman, T.P. In order to obtain the MOF of tntrza, a mixture of metal nitrates (KNO3 and AgNO3) and tntrza in methanol was used to try, and the target compounds [K­(tntrza)] n and [Ag­(tntrza)] n were successfully obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation

The preparation process of EMOFs based on dntrza and tntrza is shown in . The synthesis process of the new energetic ligand and the MOF derived therefrom is given in detail in the Supporting Information. Originally, the purpose of the reaction between tntrza and metal iodide (KI, RbI, and CsI) in methanol was to prepare a MOF based on tntrza. However, a MOF with dinitro groups ([K(dntrza)] n , [Rb(dntrza)] n , and [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ) was unexpectedly obtained. The results of this reaction are consistent with those previously reported by Kofman, T.P. In order to obtain the MOF of tntrza, a mixture of metal nitrates (KNO3 and AgNO3) and tntrza in methanol was used to try, and the target compounds [K(tntrza)] n  and [Ag(tntrza)] n  were successfully obtained.

elements.content: As an energetic ligand with high oxygen content, tntrza crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1 containing two energetic molecules and two water molecules in a unit cell. Different from the high density of energetic molecules with high oxygen balance, the crystal density of tnrza at room temperature is 1.77 g cm–3, which is caused by the water molecules in the crystal (A). Obviously, the energetic molecules in the same layer are arranged in the form of head-to-head, and there is a relatively short distance of 2.329 Å between the two heads. (with the nitroform group as the head and carboxyl as the tail) (B). It is undeniable that water molecules play an important role in the formation of hydrogen bonds in tntrza crystals (O(2)-H (2)···O (9), O(9)-H­(9A)···N (2), O(9)-H­(9A)···O­(5A), O(9)-H­(9A)···O (1), and O(9)-H­(9B)···O (1)). It not only participates in the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds in the same layer but also connects two adjacent molecular layers through hydrogen bonds (C, D).
elements.clean_text:
Structure Characteristics

As an energetic ligand with high oxygen content, tntrza crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1 containing two energetic molecules and two water molecules in a unit cell. Different from the high density of energetic molecules with high oxygen balance, the crystal density of tnrza at room temperature is 1.77 g cm-3, which is caused by the water molecules in the crystal (A). Obviously, the energetic molecules in the same layer are arranged in the form of head-to-head, and there is a relatively short distance of 2.329 Å between the two heads. (with the nitroform group as the head and carboxyl as the tail) (B). It is undeniable that water molecules play an important role in the formation of hydrogen bonds in tntrza crystals (O(2)-H (2)⋅⋅⋅O (9), O(9)-H(9A)⋅⋅⋅N (2), O(9)-H(9A)⋅⋅⋅O(5A), O(9)-H(9A)⋅⋅⋅O (1), and O(9)-H(9B)⋅⋅⋅O (1)). It not only participates in the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds in the same layer but also connects two adjacent molecular layers through hydrogen bonds (C, D).

elements.content: [K­(dntrza)] n crystallizes in the monoclinic space group Pn with a calculated density of 2.001 g cm–3. Each dntrza molecule forms a coordination bond with the surrounding six potassium, and the length of the coordination bond formed by the oxygen atom and potassium ranges from 2.8063 to 3.2864 Å, while the length of the coordination bond formed by the nitrogen atom and potassium ranges from 2.9041 to 2.9486 Å. In addition to coordinating with the oxygen atom and nitrogen atom, the potassium atom is also coordinated with the carbon atom on the carboxyl group, namely, (C3-K, (3.428 Å)), as shown in A. In the two-dimensional (2D) layer, potassium forms coordination bonds with the oxygen (O1, O2, O4, O5, and O6) and nitrogen (N2 and N3) atoms of the four surrounding energetic ligand molecules and expands into a layered structure, as shown in C. In addition to the coordination bonds, there are also abundant hydrogen bonds O(1)-H (2)···O (6), O(1)-H (2)···O (5), O(1)-H (2)···N (4), and C(1)-H (1)···O (4) (B,D), and these hydrogen bonds connect the four dntrza molecules into a closed ring (or each dntrza molecule is connected to the surrounding four dntrza molecules through hydrogen bonds) (D). It is these abundant hydrogen bonds and coordination effects that together determine the three-dimensional (3D) stacking pattern of [K­(dntrza)] n .

In addition to coordinating with the oxygen atom and nitrogen atom, the potassium atom is also coordinated with the carbon atom on the carboxyl group, namely, (C3-K, (3.428 Å)), as shown in A. elements.content: [Rb­(dntrza)] n crystallizes in the monoclinic space group Pn with a calculated density of 2.297 g cm–3 at the temperature of 170 K. Interestingly, the coordination of rubidium and dntrza is very similar to that of potassium, that is, there are six rubidium to coordinate with each dntrza molecule (A). Even so, there are differences between Rbdntrza and Kdntrza, and the main difference is reflected in the coordination of metal atoms and carbon atoms. In [Rb­(dntrza)] n , rubidium atoms and carbon atoms form three coordination bonds (Rb-C3 (3.717 Å), Rb-C4 (3.690 Å), and Rb-C4 (3.461 Å), while in [K­(dntrza)] n , there is only one kind of coordination between potassium and carbon atoms (K-C3 (3.428 Å)) (A, C). Except for the formation of coordination bonds consistent with [K­(dntrza)] n , the formation of hydrogen bonds (O5-H5···O3, O5-H5···O4, O5-H5···N1, and C2-H2···O1) is also similar to that of [K­(dntrza)] n (D).

elements.content: [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group cmca with a calculated density of 2.301 g cm–3 at the temperature of 296 K. Unlike [K­(dntrza)] n and [Rb­(dntrza)] n , each unit cell of [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n has two dntrza molecules which form coordination bonds with the surrounding 10 cesium atoms and two water molecules (A). Although there are three coordination metals in different environments, their distribution has strong regularity. That is, Cs1 and Cs2 are distributed on the vertical centerline of the crystal, and Cs3 is distributed on both the sides of the centerline (B-D). C shows the coordination of Cs3 and dntrza molecules in the same plane; each Cs3 is coordinated with two nearby dntrza molecules, and the lengths of the coordination bond are Cs3-O (3.158∼3.272 Å) and Cs3-N (3.363 Å). D shows the coordination of Cs1 and Cs2, both of which have coordinated with six energetic molecules. It is worth noting that the coordination of Cs1 and Cs2 with energetic molecules only occurs on the oxygen atom of the nitro group.

elements.content: For complex [K­(tntrza)] n , it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with a calculated density of 1.88 g cm–3 at the temperature of 296 K. Each potassium atom forms a coordination bond with eight surrounding tntrza molecules, and this can be clearly seen from A. From the top of the small diamond-shaped area at the horizontal center line of the stacking diagram (B), it is clear that the distribution of intermolecular hydrogen bonds is generated by the C–H on the triazole and the oxygen atoms on the carboxyl group (C). D shows the acute-angled top (with the angle of 58.64°) of the horizontally arranged rhombus chain. Obviously, each rhombus is not separated from each other, and they are closely connected to each other through the coordination bond K-O8 (3.200 Å). Although the tntrza molecules are arranged in a compact manner, this did not contribute to the formation of 3D-MOF (this can be clearly seen from the Supporting Information).

elements.content: As for [Ag­(tntrza)] n , its crystal belongs to triclinic space group P-1 with a calculated density of 2.595 g cm–3 at the temperature of 296 K. Each tntrza molecule forms a coordination bond with the surrounding four silver atoms (A). Unexpectedly, unlike other MOFs described above, the nitro group of [Ag­(tntrza)] n does not participate in the formation of the coordination bonds. In addition, there are only intramolecular hydrogen bonds in the crystal (C). Similar to [K­(tntrza)] n and tntrza, the adjacent 2D layers inside the crystal of [Ag­(tntrza)] n are close to each other with nitroformyl groups (the distance between the two parallel MOF blocks is 1.633 Å) (B, C), which makes the MOFs prone to generate “hot spots” in the cavities near the nitroform group that cause combustion or detonation when MOFs are subjected to external mechanical stimulation. It is worth noting that inside the 2D layer, the thin layers, as shown in C, are close to each other (with a distance of 3.11 Å) through the coordination bond Ag-N3 (2.735 Å).

elements.content: To illustrate the thermal stability and the decomposition processes of these complexes, DSC at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1, TGA at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1, and thermogravimetric mass spectrometry (TG-MS) at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 were applied. As shown in A, it is obvious that the EMOFs with tntrza and dntrza as the ligands show better thermal stability (T d = 168.1, 153.9, 144.4, 161.9, and 189.9 °C for [K­(dntrza)] n , [Rb­(dntrza)] n , [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n , [K­(tntrza)] n , and [Ag­(tntrza)] n , respectively) than the nitroform tetrazolium MOFs (RbTNTz (119.6 °C), AgTNTz (123.4 °C), and Cu­(NH3)3(TNTz)2 (117.3 °C)), and the onset decomposition temperature is also higher than that of the ligand compound tntrza (137.0 °C). Interestingly, there is a regular phenomenon between the thermal stability of the dntrza-based EMOFs and the atomic number of the alkali metal, that is, the larger the atomic number, the worse the thermal stability of the EMOFs will be. From B, it is clear that there is a significant difference in the decomposition process of the dntrza-based EMOFs and the tntrza-based EMOFs. As for the former, there are two stages of mass loss during the decomposition process. The first stage occurs at the exothermic peak in the DSC curves, which are 159∼171 °C ([K­(dntrza)] n ), 150∼157 °C ([Rb­(dntrza)] n ), and 143∼148 °C ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), respectively, and the corresponding quality loss values at this stage are 15.13, 16.75 and 14.21%, respectively. The second stage occurred in the temperature range of 173∼176 °C (K­(dntrza)] n ), 159∼162 °C ([Rb­(dntrza)] n ), and 151∼155 °C ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), and the corresponding mass loss values are 15.89, 20.16, and 11.87%, respectively, while the decomposition process of the tntrza-based EMOFs has only one stage of quality loss. As for the latter, the mass loss only occurs in the vicinity of the exothermic peak, which is 159∼171 °C ([K­(tntrza)] n ) and 190∼198 °C ([Ag­(tntrza)] n ), and the mass loss accounts for 76.14 and 45.39% of the total mass, respectively. TGA revealed that the abovementioned compounds exhibited a violent energy release process, especially the tntrza-based EMOFs. According to the TG-MS test results (), the main gas-phase products of tntrza decomposition include CH4 (16), H2O (18), HCN (27), CO (28), CH2O (30 and 29 (CHO)), N2O (44), and NO2 (46). Obviously, CH2O and N2O occupy the largest proportion in the entire gas-phase product. When tntrza reacts with metal iodides to form the dntrza-based EMOFs, the types of gas-phase products produced by decomposition are simplified compared with tntrza, and the main gas-phase products are CO, CH2O, and N2O. It is worth mentioning that with the increase in the sequence of alkali-metal atoms, the proportion of heavy gases (N2O) gradually decreases, while the proportion of light gases (CO and CH2O) increases, especially CH4 ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ). For tntrza-based EMOFs, their decomposition gas-phase product distribution is similar to that of tntrza, with the obvious difference being CH2O and NO2. In summary, the high OB can promote the decomposition of compounds, that is, it can lead to the production of more small molecule gases.

Thermal Stability and Decomposition Product Analysis

To illustrate the thermal stability and the decomposition processes of these complexes, DSC at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1, TGA at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1, and thermogravimetric mass spectrometry (TG-MS) at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 were applied. Interestingly, there is a regular phenomenon between the thermal stability of the dntrza-based EMOFs and the atomic number of the alkali metal, that is, the larger the atomic number, the worse the thermal stability of the EMOFs will be. From B, it is clear that there is a significant difference in the decomposition process of the dntrza-based EMOFs and the tntrza-based EMOFs. As for the former, there are two stages of mass loss during the decomposition process. The first stage occurs at the exothermic peak in the DSC curves, which are 159~171 °C ([K(dntrza)] n ), 150~157 °C ([Rb(dntrza)] n ), and 143~148 °C ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), respectively, and the corresponding quality loss values at this stage are 15.13, 16.75 and 14.21%, respectively. The second stage occurred in the temperature range of 173~176 °C (K(dntrza)] n ), 159~162 °C ([Rb(dntrza)] n ), and 151~155 °C ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), and the corresponding mass loss values are 15.89, 20.16, and 11.87%, respectively, while the decomposition process of the tntrza-based EMOFs has only one stage of quality loss. As for the latter, the mass loss only occurs in the vicinity of the exothermic peak, which is 159~171 °C ([K(tntrza)] n ) and 190~198 °C ([Ag(tntrza)] n ), and the mass loss accounts for 76.14 and 45.39% of the total mass, respectively. TGA revealed that the abovementioned compounds exhibited a violent energy release process, especially the tntrza-based EMOFs. According to the TG-MS test results (), the main gas-phase products of tntrza decomposition include CH4 (16), H2O (18), HCN (27), CO (28), CH2O (30 and 29 (CHO)), N2O (44), and NO2 (46). Obviously, CH2O and N2O occupy the largest proportion in the entire gas-phase product. When tntrza reacts with metal iodides to form the dntrza-based EMOFs, the types of gas-phase products produced by decomposition are simplified compared with tntrza, and the main gas-phase products are CO, CH2O, and N2O. It is worth mentioning that with the increase in the sequence of alkali-metal atoms, the proportion of heavy gases (N2O) gradually decreases, while the proportion of light gases (CO and CH2O) increases, especially CH4 ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ). For tntrza-based EMOFs, their decomposition gas-phase product distribution is similar to that of tntrza, with the obvious difference being CH2O and NO2. In summary, the high OB can promote the decomposition of compounds, that is, it can lead to the production of more small molecule gases.

Nonisothermal Kinetic Analysis

elements.content: where β is the linear heating rate (°C min–1), T P denotes the peak temperature (K) of decomposition, A represents the pre-exponential constant, R is the gas constant (8.314 J (mol °C)−1), E is the apparent activation energy (kJ mol–1), and C is a constant.

elements.content: The DSC curves of the above six compounds at the heating rates of 5, 10, 15, and 20 °C min–1 are shown in . Based on the peak temperature of decomposition at different heating rates, the nonisothermal kinetic parameters of the above six compounds can be obtained (). Obviously, the values of E calculated using the Kissinger (E k) and Ozawa (E o) methods are in good agreement with each other and range from 125.7 kJ mol–1 (tntrza) to 231.1 kJ mol–1 ([K­(tntrza)] n ). It is worth noting that tntrza-based EMOFs exhibited significantly higher E than dntrza-based EMOFs, which implies that the thermal stability of tntrza-based EMOFs is better than that of dntrza-based EMOFs. In order to further estimate the rate constant of the initial decomposition process of the six complexes and also to determine their thermal decomposition mechanism, the Arrhenius equation can be expressed as follows: lnk = 25.3 – 125.7 × 103/(RT), lnk = 24.6 – 129.6 × 103/(RT), lnk = 26.9 – 133.4 × 103/(RT), lnk = 28.9 – 137.3 × 103/(RT), lnk = 53.1 – 231.1 × 103/(RT) and lnk = 35.2 – 176.7 × 103/(RT).

elements.clean_text:
Detonation Performances and Mechanical Sensitivities

Detonation velocity (D) and pressure (P) are the particularly vital parameters used to judge the detonation performance of energetic materials. For safety purposes, the energy performances of the complexes are characterized on the basis of the highly recognized Kamlet-Jacobs - with the method proposed by S. Pang.     D = 1.01   ( N   M̅   1 / 2     Q   1 / 2   )   1 / 2    ( 1 + 1.3 ρ )    5      P = 1.558   ρ   2   N   M̅   1 / 2     Q   1 / 2     6      Q = -  ⌊ Δ   H   f    ( detonation products )  - Δ   H   f    ( explosive )  ⌋  /  ( formula weight )    7

elements.content: where D is the detonation velocity (km s–1), P is the detonation pressure (GPa), N is expressed as the number of moles of detonation gases per gram of explosive (mol g–1), M̅ is the gaseous product of the average molecular weight (g mol–1), ρ represents the density (g cm–3), and Q is the heat of detonation (kcal g–1). It should be pointed out that the calculation of the detonation velocity and the pressure of the above complexes is carried out in accordance with the explosion equation of the largest exothermic principle (H2O–CO2) (Supporting Information). For the calculation of the heat of detonation of the above energetic complexes, their constant pressure reaction heat (ΔC U) was measured using an oxygen bomb calorimeter (Supporting Information). To express the energy performance of the above complexes intuitively, their detonation velocity (D), detonation pressure (P), and heat of detonation (Q) are listed in . The calculation results show that tntrza exhibits excellent detonation performance superior to RDX and comparable to HMX, and this can be attributed to its higher density (1.82 g cm–3) and oxygen balance (−6.4%) than RDX. These favorable conditions also profoundly affect the energy performance of MOFs based on tntrza and dntrza. The obtained EMOFs show a good detonation velocity higher than 7.0 km s–1, especially for [Ag­(tntrza)]­i n . Its exceptionally high density (ρ = 2.595 g cm–3), nearly zero oxygen balance (−4.3%), and appropriate heat of detonation lead to its superior detonation properties (D = 8.74 km s–1, P = 41.1 GPa) over the energetic precursor tntrza (D = 8.72 km s–1, P = 33.9 GPa).

Friction sensitivity.

For safety evaluation, the impact and friction sensitivities of the above complexes were measured using the BAM standard method, and all the obtained data are summarized in . For energetic ligands, the nitroform structure of tntrza results in a higher mechanical sensitivity (IS = 5.0 J and FS = 100 N) than RDX. Therefore, it can be expected that the EMOF based on tntrza exhibits extremely high mechanical sensitivity, especially [Ag­(tntrza)] n (IS = 1.5 J and FS = 50 N). In general, tntrza-based MOFs exhibit higher mechanical sensitivity than dntrza-based MOFs. Among them, [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n exhibits the lowest mechanical sensitivity, which is caused by the water molecules in the crystal.

Among them, [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n  exhibits the lowest mechanical sensitivity, which is caused by the water molecules in the crystal.

elements.content: As the main oxidant of the composite solid propellants, the amount of added AP reached 60 to 90%. Unfortunately, the extremely high decomposition temperature of AP has a negative effect on the combustion performance of the propellant. It is reported that MOFs containing silver generally have a good promoting effect on the decomposition of AP. In this article, [Ag­(tntrza)] n showing an excellent overall performance (high oxygen balance, acceptable detonation performance, and thermal stability) has been reported. Therefore, the catalytic activity of [Ag­(tntrza)] n on the thermal degradation of AP was examined as a reference for its catalytic performance in the composite solid propellant (the effect of other EMOFs prepared in this study and the effect of AgNO3 on the decomposition of AP have also been explored, see the Supporting Information). The thermal decomposition curve of the same quality of pure AP (at the heating rate of 5 °C min–1) and AP mixed with 10% [Ag­(tntrza)] n (at the heating rates of 5, 10, 15, and 20 °C min–1) is shown in . The thermal decomposition of pure AP exhibits three peaks, including one endothermic peak and two exothermic peaks. The endothermic peak temperature at 241.9 °C is caused by the transformation of the crystal from orthorhombic to cubic. The first exothermic peak appeared at 311.2 °C, representing the partial decomposition of AP (LTD), and the second exothermic peak was at 420.7 °C, representing the complete decomposition of AP (HTD). As can be seen from , AP mixed with 10% [Ag­(tntrza)] n exhibits the same exothermic peak at 239.1 °C similar to pure AP, which implies that the crystal transition process of AP is hardly affected by [Ag­(tntrza)] n . As for the values of LTD and HTD, they are reduced by 47.0 and 85.5 °C, respectively, than pure AP when AP is mixed with [Ag­(tntrza)] n . [Ag­(tntrza)] n can not only make LTD and HTD advanced obviously but also weaken the peaks of HTD. This result indicated that compound [Ag­(tntrza)] n can be regarded as a catalyst to promote the thermal decomposition of AP.

elements.content: According to the four sets of heating rate and maximum decomposition temperature data, as well as , a linear equation y = – 18.614x + 19.404 with good fit (r = −0.996) can be obtained. From the slope of the fitting equation, it can be easily calculated that the activation energy of doped AP is 154.7 kJ mol–1, which is significantly lower than that of pure AP (216.0 kJ mol–1). Therefore, [Ag­(tntrza)] n not only helps improve the oxygen content but also has a good catalytic effect on AP.

elements.content: In summary, two new series of EMOFs (dntrza-based EMOFs a+nd tntrza-based EMOFs) were obtained by reacting two different metal salts (metal iodides and metal nitrates) with tntrza. Because of the difference in the structure of the ligands obtained by the two reactions, different distributions of physiochemical properties such as oxygen balance (OB: −21.1 to −4.3%) and detonation performance (D: 7.73∼8.74 km s–1 and P: 28.1∼41.1 GPa) are realized. Among them, the advantages of excellent oxygen balance and high crystal density make EMOFs with nitroform groups ([K­(tntrza)] n and [Ag­(tntrza)] n ) show more outstanding energy performance than EMOFs with dinitro groups ([K­(dntrza)] n , [Rb­(dntrza)] n , and [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), especially Ag­[tntrza] n , which not only exhibits better detonation performance (D: 8.74 km s–1 and P: 41.1 GPa) than tntrza and RDX but also exhibits an effective catalytic effect on the decomposition of AP. In addition to affecting the detonation performance of these EMOFs, this difference in oxygen balance also makes a great difference in the distribution of gas-phase products produced during decomposition. In general, compounds with high oxygen balance can produce more types of gas-phase products. In terms of thermal stability, the decomposition temperature (T dec: 144.4∼189.9 °C), the temperature of thermal explosion (T pb: 138.5∼179.5 °C), and the apparent activation energy (E: 129.6∼231.1 kJ mol–1) are significantly enhanced after the formation of EMOFs, regardless of whether it is dntrza-based EMOFs or tntrza-based EMOFs. This work not only broadens the horizons for the preparation of catalytic EMOFs with high oxygen content but also helps understand the mechanism of the thermal decomposition of EMOFs with nitroform and dinitro groups.

Conclusions

In summary, two new series of EMOFs (dntrza-based EMOFs a+nd tntrza-based EMOFs) were obtained by reacting two different metal salts (metal iodides and metal nitrates) with tntrza. Because of the difference in the structure of the ligands obtained by the two reactions, different distributions of physiochemical properties such as oxygen balance (OB: -21.1 to -4.3%) and detonation performance (D: 7.73~8.74 km s-1 and P: 28.1~41.1 GPa) are realized. Among them, the advantages of excellent oxygen balance and high crystal density make EMOFs with nitroform groups ([K(tntrza)] n  and [Ag(tntrza)] n ) show more outstanding energy performance than EMOFs with dinitro groups ([K(dntrza)] n , [Rb(dntrza)] n , and [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), especially Ag[tntrza] n , which not only exhibits better detonation performance (D: 8.74 km s-1 and P: 41.1 GPa) than tntrza and RDX but also exhibits an effective catalytic effect on the decomposition of AP. In addition to affecting the detonation performance of these EMOFs, this difference in oxygen balance also makes a great difference in the distribution of gas-phase products produced during decomposition. In general, compounds with high oxygen balance can produce more types of gas-phase products. In terms of thermal stability, the decomposition temperature (T dec: 144.4~189.9 °C), the temperature of thermal explosion (T pb: 138.5~179.5 °C), and the apparent activation energy (E: 129.6~231.1 kJ mol-1) are significantly enhanced after the formation of EMOFs, regardless of whether it is dntrza-based EMOFs or tntrza-based EMOFs. This work not only broadens the horizons for the preparation of catalytic EMOFs with high oxygen content but also helps understand the mechanism of the thermal decomposition of EMOFs with nitroform and dinitro groups.

cln_elements.content:
Energetic metal–organic frameworks (EMOFs) with a high oxygen content are currently a hot spot in the field of energetic materials research. In this article, two series of EMOFs with different ligands were obtained by reacting 1-(trinitromethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic acid (tntrza) with metal iodide and metal nitrate, respectively. Furthermore, their structure, thermal stability, thermal decomposition kinetics, and energy performance are fully characterized. The research results revealed that the synthesized EMOFs possess a wide range of density (ρ = 1.88∼2.595 g cm–3), oxygen balance (OB­(CO2) = −21.1∼ −4.3%), and acceptable energy performance (D = 7.73∼8.74 km s–1 and P = 28.1∼41.1 GPa). The difference in OB­(CO2) caused by the ligand structure and metal properties has a great impact on the distribution of gas-phase products after the decomposition of these EMOFs. Noteworthy, [Ag­(tntrza)] n is particularly prominent among these EMOFs, not only because of its excellent detonation performance (D = 8.74 km s–1 and P = 41.1 GPa) endowed by its extremely high density (ρ = 2.595 g cm–3) and oxygen balance (OB­(CO2) = −4.3%) but also because of its effective catalytic effect on the decomposition of ammonium perchlorate (AP). This article broadens the horizon for the study of oxygen-enriched EMOFs with catalytic effects and helps understand the mechanism of thermal decomposition of EMOFs with nitroform and dinitro groups.

Structure Characteristics

As an energetic ligand with high oxygen content, tntrza crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1 containing two energetic molecules and two water molecules in a unit cell. Different from the high density of energetic molecules with high oxygen balance, the crystal density of tnrza at room temperature is 1.77 g cm–3, which is caused by the water molecules in the crystal (A). Obviously, the energetic molecules in the same layer are arranged in the form of head-to-head, and there is a relatively short distance of 2.329 Å between the two heads. (with the nitroform group as the head and carboxyl as the tail) (B). It is undeniable that water molecules play an important role in the formation of hydrogen bonds in tntrza crystals (O(2)-H (2)···O (9), O(9)-H­(9A)···N (2), O(9)-H­(9A)···O­(5A), O(9)-H­(9A)···O (1), and O(9)-H­(9B)···O (1)). It not only participates in the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds in the same layer but also connects two adjacent molecular layers through hydrogen bonds (C, D).

[Rb­(dntrza)] n crystallizes in the monoclinic space group Pn with a calculated density of 2.297 g cm–3 at the temperature of 170 K. Interestingly, the coordination of rubidium and dntrza is very similar to that of potassium, that is, there are six rubidium to coordinate with each dntrza molecule (A). Even so, there are differences between Rbdntrza and Kdntrza, and the main difference is reflected in the coordination of metal atoms and carbon atoms. In [Rb­(dntrza)] n , rubidium atoms and carbon atoms form three coordination bonds (Rb-C3 (3.717 Å), Rb-C4 (3.690 Å), and Rb-C4 (3.461 Å), while in [K­(dntrza)] n , there is only one kind of coordination between potassium and carbon atoms (K-C3 (3.428 Å)) (A, C). Except for the formation of coordination bonds consistent with [K­(dntrza)] n , the formation of hydrogen bonds (O5-H5···O3, O5-H5···O4, O5-H5···N1, and C2-H2···O1) is also similar to that of [K­(dntrza)] n (D).

[Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group cmca with a calculated density of 2.301 g cm–3 at the temperature of 296 K. Unlike [K­(dntrza)] n and [Rb­(dntrza)] n , each unit cell of [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n has two dntrza molecules which form coordination bonds with the surrounding 10 cesium atoms and two water molecules (A). Although there are three coordination metals in different environments, their distribution has strong regularity. That is, Cs1 and Cs2 are distributed on the vertical centerline of the crystal, and Cs3 is distributed on both the sides of the centerline (B-D). C shows the coordination of Cs3 and dntrza molecules in the same plane; each Cs3 is coordinated with two nearby dntrza molecules, and the lengths of the coordination bond are Cs3-O (3.158∼3.272 Å) and Cs3-N (3.363 Å). D shows the coordination of Cs1 and Cs2, both of which have coordinated with six energetic molecules. It is worth noting that the coordination of Cs1 and Cs2 with energetic molecules only occurs on the oxygen atom of the nitro group.

For complex [K­(tntrza)] n , it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with a calculated density of 1.88 g cm–3 at the temperature of 296 K. Each potassium atom forms a coordination bond with eight surrounding tntrza molecules, and this can be clearly seen from A. From the top of the small diamond-shaped area at the horizontal center line of the stacking diagram (B), it is clear that the distribution of intermolecular hydrogen bonds is generated by the C–H on the triazole and the oxygen atoms on the carboxyl group (C). D shows the acute-angled top (with the angle of 58.64°) of the horizontally arranged rhombus chain. Obviously, each rhombus is not separated from each other, and they are closely connected to each other through the coordination bond K-O8 (3.200 Å). Although the tntrza molecules are arranged in a compact manner, this did not contribute to the formation of 3D-MOF (this can be clearly seen from the Supporting Information).

As for [Ag­(tntrza)] n , its crystal belongs to triclinic space group P-1 with a calculated density of 2.595 g cm–3 at the temperature of 296 K. Each tntrza molecule forms a coordination bond with the surrounding four silver atoms (A). Unexpectedly, unlike other MOFs described above, the nitro group of [Ag­(tntrza)] n does not participate in the formation of the coordination bonds. In addition, there are only intramolecular hydrogen bonds in the crystal (C). Similar to [K­(tntrza)] n and tntrza, the adjacent 2D layers inside the crystal of [Ag­(tntrza)] n are close to each other with nitroformyl groups (the distance between the two parallel MOF blocks is 1.633 Å) (B, C), which makes the MOFs prone to generate “hot spots” in the cavities near the nitroform group that cause combustion or detonation when MOFs are subjected to external mechanical stimulation. It is worth noting that inside the 2D layer, the thin layers, as shown in C, are close to each other (with a distance of 3.11 Å) through the coordination bond Ag-N3 (2.735 Å).

Thermal Stability and Decomposition Product Analysis

To illustrate the thermal stability and the decomposition processes of these complexes, DSC at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1, TGA at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1, and thermogravimetric mass spectrometry (TG-MS) at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 were applied. As shown in A, it is obvious that the EMOFs with tntrza and dntrza as the ligands show better thermal stability (T d = 168.1, 153.9, 144.4, 161.9, and 189.9 °C for [K­(dntrza)] n , [Rb­(dntrza)] n , [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n , [K­(tntrza)] n , and [Ag­(tntrza)] n , respectively) than the nitroform tetrazolium MOFs (RbTNTz (119.6 °C), AgTNTz (123.4 °C), and Cu­(NH3)3(TNTz)2 (117.3 °C)), and the onset decomposition temperature is also higher than that of the ligand compound tntrza (137.0 °C). Interestingly, there is a regular phenomenon between the thermal stability of the dntrza-based EMOFs and the atomic number of the alkali metal, that is, the larger the atomic number, the worse the thermal stability of the EMOFs will be. From B, it is clear that there is a significant difference in the decomposition process of the dntrza-based EMOFs and the tntrza-based EMOFs. As for the former, there are two stages of mass loss during the decomposition process. The first stage occurs at the exothermic peak in the DSC curves, which are 159∼171 °C ([K­(dntrza)] n ), 150∼157 °C ([Rb­(dntrza)] n ), and 143∼148 °C ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), respectively, and the corresponding quality loss values at this stage are 15.13, 16.75 and 14.21%, respectively. The second stage occurred in the temperature range of 173∼176 °C (K­(dntrza)] n ), 159∼162 °C ([Rb­(dntrza)] n ), and 151∼155 °C ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), and the corresponding mass loss values are 15.89, 20.16, and 11.87%, respectively, while the decomposition process of the tntrza-based EMOFs has only one stage of quality loss. As for the latter, the mass loss only occurs in the vicinity of the exothermic peak, which is 159∼171 °C ([K­(tntrza)] n ) and 190∼198 °C ([Ag­(tntrza)] n ), and the mass loss accounts for 76.14 and 45.39% of the total mass, respectively. TGA revealed that the abovementioned compounds exhibited a violent energy release process, especially the tntrza-based EMOFs. According to the TG-MS test results (), the main gas-phase products of tntrza decomposition include CH4 (16), H2O (18), HCN (27), CO (28), CH2O (30 and 29 (CHO)), N2O (44), and NO2 (46). Obviously, CH2O and N2O occupy the largest proportion in the entire gas-phase product. When tntrza reacts with metal iodides to form the dntrza-based EMOFs, the types of gas-phase products produced by decomposition are simplified compared with tntrza, and the main gas-phase products are CO, CH2O, and N2O. It is worth mentioning that with the increase in the sequence of alkali-metal atoms, the proportion of heavy gases (N2O) gradually decreases, while the proportion of light gases (CO and CH2O) increases, especially CH4 ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ). For tntrza-based EMOFs, their decomposition gas-phase product distribution is similar to that of tntrza, with the obvious difference being CH2O and NO2. In summary, the high OB can promote the decomposition of compounds, that is, it can lead to the production of more small molecule gases.

For complex [K(tntrza)] n , it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with a calculated density of 1.88 g cm-3 at the temperature of 296 K. Each potassium atom forms a coordination bond with eight surrounding tntrza molecules, and this can be clearly seen from A. From the top of the small diamond-shaped area at the horizontal center line of the stacking diagram (B), it is clear that the distribution of intermolecular hydrogen bonds is generated by the C-H on the triazole and the oxygen atoms on the carboxyl group (C). D shows the acute-angled top (with the angle of 58.64°) of the horizontally arranged rhombus chain. Obviously, each rhombus is not separated from each other, and they are closely connected to each other through the coordination bond K-O8 (3.200 Å). Although the tntrza molecules are arranged in a compact manner, this did not contribute to the formation of 3D-MOF (this can be clearly seen from the Supporting Information).

As for [Ag(tntrza)] n , its crystal belongs to triclinic space group P-1 with a calculated density of 2.595 g cm-3 at the temperature of 296 K. Each tntrza molecule forms a coordination bond with the surrounding four silver atoms (A). Unexpectedly, unlike other MOFs described above, the nitro group of [Ag(tntrza)] n  does not participate in the formation of the coordination bonds. In addition, there are only intramolecular hydrogen bonds in the crystal (C). Similar to [K(tntrza)] n  and tntrza, the adjacent 2D layers inside the crystal of [Ag(tntrza)] n  are close to each other with nitroformyl groups (the distance between the two parallel MOF blocks is 1.633 Å) (B, C), which makes the MOFs prone to generate "hot spots" in the cavities near the nitroform group that cause combustion or detonation when MOFs are subjected to external mechanical stimulation. It is worth noting that inside the 2D layer, the thin layers, as shown in C, are close to each other (with a distance of 3.11 Å) through the coordination bond Ag-N3 (2.735 Å).

Thermal Stability and Decomposition Product Analysis

To illustrate the thermal stability and the decomposition processes of these complexes, DSC at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1, TGA at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1, and thermogravimetric mass spectrometry (TG-MS) at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 were applied. As shown in A, it is obvious that the EMOFs with tntrza and dntrza as the ligands show better thermal stability (T d = 168.1, 153.9, 144.4, 161.9, and 189.9 °C for [K(dntrza)] n , [Rb(dntrza)] n , [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n , [K(tntrza)] n , and [Ag(tntrza)] n , respectively) than the nitroform tetrazolium MOFs (RbTNTz (119.6 °C), AgTNTz (123.4 °C), and Cu(NH3)3(TNTz)2 (117.3 °C)), and the onset decomposition temperature is also higher than that of the ligand compound tntrza (137.0 °C). Interestingly, there is a regular phenomenon between the thermal stability of the dntrza-based EMOFs and the atomic number of the alkali metal, that is, the larger the atomic number, the worse the thermal stability of the EMOFs will be. From B, it is clear that there is a significant difference in the decomposition process of the dntrza-based EMOFs and the tntrza-based EMOFs. As for the former, there are two stages of mass loss during the decomposition process. The first stage occurs at the exothermic peak in the DSC curves, which are 159~171 °C ([K(dntrza)] n ), 150~157 °C ([Rb(dntrza)] n ), and 143~148 °C ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), respectively, and the corresponding quality loss values at this stage are 15.13, 16.75 and 14.21%, respectively. The second stage occurred in the temperature range of 173~176 °C (K(dntrza)] n ), 159~162 °C ([Rb(dntrza)] n ), and 151~155 °C ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ), and the corresponding mass loss values are 15.89, 20.16, and 11.87%, respectively, while the decomposition process of the tntrza-based EMOFs has only one stage of quality loss. As for the latter, the mass loss only occurs in the vicinity of the exothermic peak, which is 159~171 °C ([K(tntrza)] n ) and 190~198 °C ([Ag(tntrza)] n ), and the mass loss accounts for 76.14 and 45.39% of the total mass, respectively. TGA revealed that the abovementioned compounds exhibited a violent energy release process, especially the tntrza-based EMOFs. According to the TG-MS test results (), the main gas-phase products of tntrza decomposition include CH4 (16), H2O (18), HCN (27), CO (28), CH2O (30 and 29 (CHO)), N2O (44), and NO2 (46). Obviously, CH2O and N2O occupy the largest proportion in the entire gas-phase product. When tntrza reacts with metal iodides to form the dntrza-based EMOFs, the types of gas-phase products produced by decomposition are simplified compared with tntrza, and the main gas-phase products are CO, CH2O, and N2O. It is worth mentioning that with the increase in the sequence of alkali-metal atoms, the proportion of heavy gases (N2O) gradually decreases, while the proportion of light gases (CO and CH2O) increases, especially CH4 ([Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n ). For tntrza-based EMOFs, their decomposition gas-phase product distribution is similar to that of tntrza, with the obvious difference being CH2O and NO2. In summary, the high OB can promote the decomposition of compounds, that is, it can lead to the production of more small molecule gases.

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules

cln_elements.content:
The DSC curves of the above six compounds at the heating rates of 5, 10, 15, and 20 °C min–1 are shown in . Based on the peak temperature of decomposition at different heating rates, the nonisothermal kinetic parameters of the above six compounds can be obtained (). Obviously, the values of E calculated using the Kissinger (E k) and Ozawa (E o) methods are in good agreement with each other and range from 125.7 kJ mol–1 (tntrza) to 231.1 kJ mol–1 ([K­(tntrza)] n ). It is worth noting that tntrza-based EMOFs exhibited significantly higher E than dntrza-based EMOFs, which implies that the thermal stability of tntrza-based EMOFs is better than that of dntrza-based EMOFs. In order to further estimate the rate constant of the initial decomposition process of the six complexes and also to determine their thermal decomposition mechanism, the Arrhenius equation can be expressed as follows: lnk = 25.3 – 125.7 × 103/(RT), lnk = 24.6 – 129.6 × 103/(RT), lnk = 26.9 – 133.4 × 103/(RT), lnk = 28.9 – 137.3 × 103/(RT), lnk = 53.1 – 231.1 × 103/(RT) and lnk = 35.2 – 176.7 × 103/(RT).

where D is the detonation velocity (km s–1), P is the detonation pressure (GPa), N is expressed as the number of moles of detonation gases per gram of explosive (mol g–1), M̅ is the gaseous product of the average molecular weight (g mol–1), ρ represents the density (g cm–3), and Q is the heat of detonation (kcal g–1). It should be pointed out that the calculation of the detonation velocity and the pressure of the above complexes is carried out in accordance with the explosion equation of the largest exothermic principle (H2O–CO2) (Supporting Information). For the calculation of the heat of detonation of the above energetic complexes, their constant pressure reaction heat (ΔC U) was measured using an oxygen bomb calorimeter (Supporting Information). To express the energy performance of the above complexes intuitively, their detonation velocity (D), detonation pressure (P), and heat of detonation (Q) are listed in . The calculation results show that tntrza exhibits excellent detonation performance superior to RDX and comparable to HMX, and this can be attributed to its higher density (1.82 g cm–3) and oxygen balance (−6.4%) than RDX. These favorable conditions also profoundly affect the energy performance of MOFs based on tntrza and dntrza. The obtained EMOFs show a good detonation velocity higher than 7.0 km s–1, especially for [Ag­(tntrza)]­i n . Its exceptionally high density (ρ = 2.595 g cm–3), nearly zero oxygen balance (−4.3%), and appropriate heat of detonation lead to its superior detonation properties (D = 8.74 km s–1, P = 41.1 GPa) over the energetic precursor tntrza (D = 8.72 km s–1, P = 33.9 GPa).

For safety evaluation, the impact and friction sensitivities of the above complexes were measured using the BAM standard method, and all the obtained data are summarized in . For energetic ligands, the nitroform structure of tntrza results in a higher mechanical sensitivity (IS = 5.0 J and FS = 100 N) than RDX. Therefore, it can be expected that the EMOF based on tntrza exhibits extremely high mechanical sensitivity, especially [Ag­(tntrza)] n (IS = 1.5 J and FS = 50 N). In general, tntrza-based MOFs exhibit higher mechanical sensitivity than dntrza-based MOFs. Among them, [Cs3(dntrza)2(H2O)3] n exhibits the lowest mechanical sensitivity, which is caused by the water molecules in the crystal.

Effects on the Decomposition of AP

As the main oxidant of the composite solid propellants, the amount of added AP reached 60 to 90%. Unfortunately, the extremely high decomposition temperature of AP has a negative effect on the combustion performance of the propellant. It is reported that MOFs containing silver generally have a good promoting effect on the decomposition of AP. In this article, [Ag­(tntrza)] n showing an excellent overall performance (high oxygen balance, acceptable detonation performance, and thermal stability) has been reported. Therefore, the catalytic activity of [Ag­(tntrza)] n on the thermal degradation of AP was examined as a reference for its catalytic performance in the composite solid propellant (the effect of other EMOFs prepared in this study and the effect of AgNO3 on the decomposition of AP have also been explored, see the Supporting Information). The thermal decomposition curve of the same quality of pure AP (at the heating rate of 5 °C min–1) and AP mixed with 10% [Ag­(tntrza)] n (at the heating rates of 5, 10, 15, and 20 °C min–1) is shown in . The thermal decomposition of pure AP exhibits three peaks, including one endothermic peak and two exothermic peaks. The endothermic peak temperature at 241.9 °C is caused by the transformation of the crystal from orthorhombic to cubic. The first exothermic peak appeared at 311.2 °C, representing the partial decomposition of AP (LTD), and the second exothermic peak was at 420.7 °C, representing the complete decomposition of AP (HTD). As can be seen from , AP mixed with 10% [Ag­(tntrza)] n exhibits the same exothermic peak at 239.1 °C similar to pure AP, which implies that the crystal transition process of AP is hardly affected by [Ag­(tntrza)] n . As for the values of LTD and HTD, they are reduced by 47.0 and 85.5 °C, respectively, than pure AP when AP is mixed with [Ag­(tntrza)] n . [Ag­(tntrza)] n can not only make LTD and HTD advanced obviously but also weaken the peaks of HTD. This result indicated that compound [Ag­(tntrza)] n can be regarded as a catalyst to promote the thermal decomposition of AP.
